quotes: Ordinary Session, Kampala, 1975.

United Nations General Assembly, Report of the Special Committee on the Situation with Regard to the Implementation of the Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples (A/31/23/Rev.1), 1976, 2.
Accessed 22 May 2014.
(accessed 26 May 2014).
GM Khadiagala, Allies in adversity: The frontline states in southern African security, 1975–1993, Athens: Ohio University Press, 1994, 100–101.
South Africa occupied the territory in 1915 during World War I in the hope of annexing the region to its own borders.
Then, in 1920, the League of Nations provided South Africa with a Class C mandate to administer the territory.
This was despite a 1946 UNGA recommendation to do so.
United Nations General Assembly, Resolution 2145 (XXI), Question of South West Africa, 27 October 1966,
(accessed 3 June 2014).

International Court of Justice, Advisory Opinion – Legal Consequences for States of the Continued Presence of South Africa in Namibia (South-West Africa) Notwithstanding Security Council Resolution 276 (1970), 21 June 1971,
UN General Assembly, Resolution 3111 (XXVIII), 12 December 1973,
UN General Assembly, Resolution 31/146, Situation in Namibia Resulting from the Illegal Occupation of the Territory by South Africa, 20 December 1976,
(accessed 6 June 2014).
United Nations Security Council, Resolution 385 (S/RES/385), 1976,
(accessed 22 May 2014).
